spell.name: Vine Whip
entries: A small, multi-pronged vine grows from the ground at a point you choose within range. The vine lasts for the duration or until you dismiss it as an action. The vine withers if it is ever more than 30 feet away from you or if you cast this spell again. The vine cannot be made invisible, so you must roll a Stealth ability check to keep it from being noticed.

You can use your action to control the vine. You can use the vine to manipulate an object, open an unlocked door or container, stow or retrieve an item from an open container, or pour the contents out of a vial. You can stretch the vine up to 30 feet each time you use it.
The vine can't attack, activate magic items, or carry more than 10 pounds.

components.m: * (the stem of a plant with leaves attached)

subclass.name: Way of the Victorious Soul
subclassFeatures: If You Ain't First, You're Last|Monk|PHB|Victorious Soul|HeroesOfSarlona|3|HeroesOfSarlona
Harder Than Diamonds In An Icestorm|Monk|PHB|Victorious Soul|HeroesOfSarlona|11|HeroesOfSarlona

subclassFeature.name: Shake and Bake
entries: You were born for the spotlight, and thrive even when everyone thinks you're a laughing stock, 'cause you're a born champion. The roar of the crowd lives inside you. And little do they know, you're just a big hairy winning machine.
Starting when you choose this tradition at 3rd level, your ki save DC becomes 8 + Your Proficiency Bonus + Your Charisma Modifier (Instead of Wisdom).

You can choose to use Strength (instead of Dexterity) or Charisma (instead of Wisdom) when calculating your Monk's Unarmored Defense. Your Unarmored Defense is now calculated as follows: while you are wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, your AC equals 10 + your STR/DEX modifier + your CHA/WIS modifier.

subclassFeature.name: If You Ain't First, You're Last
entries: Pole Position: When you roll for initiative, you roll 1d20 twice, taking the number furthest from 10.
Instinctual Domination: You can attempt to grapple any creatures up to size large. If you fail to grapple a creature with a size larger than you, you take one level of exhaustion.
Flurry of Spells: When you expend a Ki Point to use your Flurry of Blows, you can cast a spell with a casting time of 1 action as a bonus action instead of making unarmed strikes.

subclassFeature.name: Enhanced Martial Discipline
entries: Uncanny Metabolism: When you roll Initiative, you can regain all expended Ki Points. When you do so, roll your Martial Arts die, and regain a number of Hit Points equal to your Monk level plus the number rolled. Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a Long Rest.

Deflect Attacks: You can use your Reaction to deflect melee and ranged attacks against you that deal Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing damage. When you do so, the total damage you take from the attack is reduced by 1d10 plus your Dexterity modifier plus your Monk level. If you reduce the damage to 0, you can spend 1 Ki Point to redirect some of the attack’s force. If you do so, choose a creature within 5 feet of you if the attack was a melee attack or 60 feet of yourself that isn’t behind Total Cover if the attack was a ranged attack. That creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take damage equal to two rolls of your Martial Arts die plus your Dexterity modifier. The damage is the same type dealt by the attack.
Bonus Unarmed Strike: You can make one Unarmed Strike as a Bonus Action.

Dexterous Attacks: You can use Dexterity instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls of your Unarmed Strikes and Monk Weapons. In addition, when you choose the Grapple or Shove option, you can use your Dexterity modifier instead of Strength to determine the saving throw DC. When you have successfully grappled a creature, you decide whether the creature must make a Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check to escape your grasp.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you gain the ability to cast spells. See Spell Rules for the general rules of spellcasting and the Spells Listing for the wizard spell list.
Arcane Focus: You can use a monk weapon as an arcane focus for your spellcasting.
Cantrips: You learn two cantrips of your choice from the wizard spell list. You learn an additional wizard cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

Spell Slots: The Way of the Arcane Hand Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your wizard spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell’s level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest. For example, if you know the 1st-level spell thunderwave and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast thunderwave using either slot.

Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher: You know three 1st-level wizard spells of your choice. The Spells Known column of the Way of the Arcane Hand Spellcasting table shows when you learn more wizard spells of 1st level or higher of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level. Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the wizard spells you know with another spell of your choice from the wizard spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

Spellcasting Ability: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your wizard spells, since you learn your spells through contemplation and meditation.. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a wizard spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.
Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier

subclassFeature.name: Slingshot, Engage!
entries: Starting at 6th level, while you are concentrating on a spell, you add twice the spell’s level to the damage rolls of your unarmed strikes and attacks made with monk weapons.
Spell Fury: Whenever you take the Attack action on your turn, you can cast one of your cantrips in place of one of your melee attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Harder Than Diamonds In An Icestorm
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against spells and magical effects. Furthermore, you have resistance to damage from spells and magical effects.

Focused Excellence: When you cast a spell, you can expend ki points to increase the level of the spell as if you’d cast the spell using a higher-level spell slot. You must use a spell slot as normal to cast the spell, then expend 1 ki point for each level you increase the spell in this way. You can increase the spell’s level higher than your highest-level spell slot to a maximum level equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Hot, Nasty, Badass Speed
entries: Starting at 17th level, when you cast a spell with a casting time of 1 action that requires your concentration, you can expend ki points equal to the spell’s level to modify the spell so that it does not require your concentration. Instead, the spell lasts up to 1 minute, or its maximum duration, whichever is shorter.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you gain the ability to cast spells. See Spells Rules for the general rules of spellcasting and the Spells Listing for the druid spell list.
Cantrips: You learn three cantrips: Vine Whip and two other cantrips of your choice from the druid spell list. You learn another druid cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

Spell Slots: The Feyblade Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your druid spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell’s level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell charm person and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast charm person using either slot.
Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher: You know three 1st-level druid spells of your choice, two of which you must choose from the enchantment and divination spells on the druid spell list.

The Spells Known column of the Feyblade Spellcasting table shows when you learn more druid spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be an enchantment, abjuration, or divination spell of your choice, and must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.
The spells you learn at 8th, 14th, and 20th level can come from any school of magic.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the druid spells you know with another spell of your choice from the druid spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots, and it must be an enchantment, abjuration, or divination spell, unless you’re replacing the spell you gained at 3rd, 8th, 14th, or 20th level from any school of magic.

Spellcasting Ability: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your druid spells, since you learn your spells through dedicated study and memorization. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a druid spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.
Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier

subclassFeature.name: Vine Manipulation
entries: Starting at 3rd level, when you cast Vine Whip, you can perform the following additional tasks with it:
You can stow one object the whip is holding in a container worn or carried by another creature.
You can retrieve an object in a container worn or carried by another creature.
You can use thieves’ tools to pick locks and disarm traps at range.
You can perform one of these tasks without being noticed by a creature if you succeed on a Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check contested by the creature’s Wisdom (Perception) check.
In addition, you can use the bonus action granted by your Cunning Action to control the whip.

subclassFeature.name: Animalistic Ambusher
entries: Starting at 9th level, if you are hidden from a creature when you cast a spell on it, the creature has disadvantage on any saving throw it makes against the spell this turn.

subclassFeature.name: Natural Trickster
entries: At 13th level, you gain the ability to distract targets with your Vine Whip. As a bonus action on your turn, you can designate a creature within 5 feet of the whip created by the spell. Doing so gives you advantage on attack rolls against that creature until the end of the turn.

subclassFeature.name: Restorative Magics
entries: You've achieved a significant synchronization with natural and restorative magics. At 17th level, you can now use your reaction to reduce the damage of any attack by 1d10 plus your spellcasting attack bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Path of Planar Chaos
entries: In the vast tapestry of existence, where realms collide and the laws of reality waver, there are those barbarians who harness the chaotic forces of the planes. Known as the Path of Planar Chaos, these untamed warriors tap into the raw energies of space, time, gravity, potential, and probabilities. Their bodies become conduits for the unpredictable, embracing the uncontrollable nature of the multiverse itself. Elf, tiefling, aasimar, and genasi barbarians are often drawn to this path, driven by their ancestral ties to the planes and a hunger for the untamed power it offers.

subclassFeature.name: Chaos Burst
entries: At level 3, you can choose to deal extra damage on an attack with a chaos burst. This allows you to add additional damage dice to an attack with a melee weapon a number of times per day equal to your proficiency bonus.
The damage is equal to 2d4. The damage die increases at higher levels, becoming 2d6 at 6th level and 2d8 at 14th level.

subclassFeature.name: Planar Force
entries: At level 3, you invoke a Planar Force when you rage. Roll 1d4 to determine the type of rage you experience.
Once per round, you can use a free action to roll 1d4 in an attempt to change the planar forces affecting you, taking 1d4 psychic damage in the process.

entries.caption: Planar Force
rows: Time Acceleration: You gain an additional action each round.
Gravitational Force: Your movement speed is doubled.
Potential Energy: Your strength modifier is doubled for all strength-based checks.
Probability Distortion: You can roll twice on any attack roll or saving throw, taking the higher result.

subclassFeature.name: Extraplanar Force
entries: At level 6, your connection to the planes deepens, allowing you to summon an extraplanar ally. You can cast summon planar ally once per day without expending a spell slot.

subclassFeature.name: Erratic Defense
entries: At level 10, the chaotic energies surrounding you grant you the ability to evade attacks with unpredictable movements. You can add your proficiency bonus to your AC for one attack. This ability can be used a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Cacophony of Chaos
entries: At level 14, you can unleash a cacophony of chaotic energy as an action, causing all enemies within 30 feet to make a Wisdom saving throw (DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier). On a failure, they are affected by the confusion spell for 1 minute.
